;;2023 年 10 月 19 日，英国首相里希·苏纳克 (Rishi Sunak) 降落在以色列特拉维夫附近罗德的本古里安国际机场后散步。 REUTERS/ Ronen Zvulun;
;

;周四，以色列对加沙进行了更多空袭，英国首相里希·苏纳克(Rishi Sunak)跟随美国总统乔·拜登访问加沙，以展示对哈马斯战争的支持，同时敦促以色列放松对加沙的制裁。被围困的加沙人的困境。

;

;苏纳克在拜登离开几小时后抵达特拉维夫，他借用了丘吉尔的一句话，承诺在哈马斯 10 月 7 日的暴行后“在最黑暗的时刻”支持以色列杀害 1,400 名以色列人的枪手。

;

;“最重要的是，我来这里是为了表达我对以色列人民的声援。你们遭受了难以形容的、可怕的恐怖主义行为，我想让你们知道，英国我与你们站在一起，”苏纳克在着陆后对以色列记者说。

;

;后来出现在总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡身边，他说：“我知道你们正在采取一切预防措施避免伤害平民，这与哈马斯的恐怖分子试图让平民陷入危险。”

;

;拜登在经过八个小时的旅行后于周三晚上飞回家，他承诺与以色列站在一起，但在他的其他任务中只取得了有限的成功，说服以色列以色列将缓解 230 万加沙人遭受全面围困的困境。

;

;拜登表示，他已获得埃及的提议，允许 20 辆救援卡车在未来几天内抵达加沙，但仍只是每天 100 辆救援卡车的一小部分联合国援助负责人马丁·格里菲斯告诉安理会，这是必要的。

;

;两个埃及安全来源;上述设备已于周四通过过境点发送，用于修复加沙一侧的道路，以便援助过境。超过 100 辆卡车在埃及一侧等待，但预计最早不会在周五之前通过。

;

;以色列表示将允许有限的援助从埃及抵达加沙，但条件是这些援助不能使哈马斯受益。它重申了自己的立场，即只有当枪手劫持的 200 多名人质全部获释后，它才会开放自己的检查站以允许援助进入。

;

;并且明确表示不会有任何松懈在其轰炸行动中：“在加沙地带，哈马斯接触过或正在接触的每一个地方都将受到打击和摧毁，”以色列拉马特大卫空军基地指挥官上校告诉公共广播公司 Kan。

;

;“我们确实是一台战争机器，知道如何做现在所做的事情的两到三倍。”

;

;加沙居民对承诺仅向 230 万人提供 20 卡车援助的姿态嗤之以鼻。食品、水、燃料和医疗用品。

;

;“关于援助，这是一些无聊的事情。除了阻止对我们房屋的暴力轰炸外，我们不需要阿拉伯国家和外国的任何东西，”阿瓦德说65 岁的 El-Dali 在房屋废墟附近发表讲话。

;

;卫生官员表示，迄今为止，爆炸事件已造成近 3,500 人死亡，12,000 多人受伤。

;

;在汗尤尼斯 (Khan Younis)，加沙地带南部，一望无际的商店被夷为废墟，一张幼儿的粉红色婴儿床翻倒在地，一家服装店的窗户被炸飞，车辆受损。

;

;拉法特·纳卡拉 (Rafat Al-Nakhala) 在遵守以色列命令平民逃离北部加沙城后来到这里，他说没有地方是安全的。

;

;“我已经 70 多岁了，我经历过好几次战争，从来没有像现在这样，从来没有如此残酷，没有宗教，没有良心。感谢上帝。我们只对上帝抱有希望，而不是对任何阿拉伯或穆斯林国家或世界上任何人抱有希望，除了上帝。”

;

;在汗尤尼斯的其他地方，一名男子亲吻了裹着裹尸布的小婴儿的尸体。它被埋进坟墓里。哀悼者说，四名小孩被埋在那里，另外三名儿童被埋在另一个地点，其中一家人在一栋三层建筑被击中时丧生。

;

;在加沙北部，路透社获得的镜头来自贾巴利亚难民营的照片显示，居民们徒手在受损的建筑物内挖掘，以解救被困在砖石下的小男孩和小女孩。当居民试图用担架照亮现场时，一具男子的尸体被用担架从废墟中拖了出来。手机上的手电筒。

;

;联合国表示，大约一半的加沙人无家可归，仍然被困在飞地内，这是地球上人口最稠密的地方之一。

;

;加沙平民的困境激怒了中东地区，使得拜登和其他西方领导人更难团结阿拉伯盟友阻止战争蔓延。

;

;拜登访问前夕，加沙一家医院发生爆炸他与阿拉伯领导人会面的计划泡汤了，阿拉伯领导人取消了与他的峰会。巴勒斯坦人将爆炸归咎于以色列的空袭；以色列称这是巴勒斯坦武装分子火箭发射失败造成的，拜登表示美国的证据支持以色列的说法。

;

;苏纳克成为自战争爆发以来第一位访问阿拉伯国家的西方领导人出去。他原定在以色列之后前往沙特阿拉伯会见王储穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼，在哈马斯袭击之前，王储一直处于同意与以色列实现关系正常化的边缘。

;

;拜登离开之前，他做了呼吁以色列人控制愤怒：“当你感到愤怒时，不要被它吞噬。9/11之后，我们在美国被激怒了。在我们寻求正义并得到正义的同时，我们也做出了”

;

;后来他在空军一号上告诉记者：“以色列受到了严重的伤害，但事实是他们有机会减轻无处可去的人们的痛苦......这是他们应该做的做。”

; Thu, 19 Oct 2023 20:25:02 +0800 Aid to move over Egyptian border unlikely to raise spirits in struggling Gazahttps://reuters.com/article/israel-palestinians-gaza/aid-to-move-over-egyptian-border-unlikely-to-raise-spirits-in-struggling-gaza-idUSKBN31J12C

;;运载埃及非政府组织为巴勒斯坦人提供的人道主义援助的卡车，等待埃及一侧拉法过境点的重新开放，进入加沙，以色列和巴勒斯坦伊斯兰组织哈马斯之间持续不断的冲突，2023 年 10 月 17 日，埃及拉法。 REUTERS/Stringer/File Photo;
;

;20 卡车援助物资将通过埃及边境运输不太可能提振陷入困境的加沙地带的士气，那里的巴勒斯坦人正专注于从以色列空袭中幸存下来以及严重的食品和药品短缺。

;

;;密集外交;，埃及同意;重新开放与加沙的过境点;，以允许援助到达巴勒斯坦人，因为人道主义援助被困在那里的 230 万人和;反以色列抗议活动;使危机进一步恶化a>; 席卷整个中东地区。

;

;“关于援助，这是一些无聊的事情，除了阻止对我们房屋的暴力轰炸外，我们不需要阿拉伯国家和外国的任何东西，”阿瓦德·埃尔- 65 岁的达利在房屋废墟旁发表讲话。

;

;像加沙和其他地方的许多巴勒斯坦人一样，他认为阿拉伯国家在支持巴勒斯坦事业方面做得不够，特别是那些与以色列实现关系正常化的国家。< /p>;

;“我们希望他们停止轰炸那些在自己房屋内被杀的人，”他说。

;

;美国和埃及一直在推动与以色列达成协议，以获得向加沙运送援助物资，白宫周三表示已同意向加沙运送最多 20 辆卡车 ;未来几天将通过;从埃及出发的拉法过境点，希望稍后会有更多卡车。

;

;以色列重申将在哈马斯释放 10 月 7 日跨境袭击以色列期间扣押的约 200 名人质之前，不允许援助通过加沙。哈马斯武装分子在袭击中杀害了约 1,400 人。

;

;大多数加沙居民依赖据联合国称，甚至在当前冲突开始之前，每天就有大约 100 辆卡车向该飞地提供人道主义救援物资。

;

;加沙卫生部表示，以色列空袭已导致 3,478 名巴勒斯坦人丧生，12,065 人受伤自 10 月 7 日以来，针对被围困飞地的袭击不断发生。

;

;加沙;Al-Ahli al-Arabi 医院; 周二晚间，巴勒斯坦官员称该医院造成 471 人死亡。他们将爆炸归咎于以色列的空袭，而以色列则称这是巴勒斯坦武装分子火箭发射失败造成的。

;

;加沙居民与外界隔绝，对这起事件知之甚少。国际外交旨在缓和因管理加沙的哈马斯渗透以色列并发动致命横行而爆发的冲突。

;

;自哈马斯 2007 年控制加沙以来，以色列和埃及一直维持对加沙的封锁，严格控制货物和人员的流动。

;

;多年来，加沙人在哈马斯和以色列之间的战争、封锁以及世界上人口最稠密地区之一的失业中幸存下来，恢复力不断增强。

;

; >;

;但哈马斯袭击是自 1973 年赎罪日战争以来针对以色列最大规模的袭击，随后以色列对加沙进行了有史以来最猛烈的袭击，造成了一场巨大的危机。

;

;大家庭聚集在一个地方，感受到安全感。但这来之不易。

;

;“我的家倒塌了。我的女儿，她是家里的花，死了。看看这些孩子，他们和我一样受过伤，他们带走了我们从废墟中爬出来。我们有什么错？”流离失所、现在住在帐篷里的霍达·阿拉法特说。

;

;“有一名妇女在废墟下尖叫：‘救救我们，救救我的儿媳妇，她在流血’。”

;

;几乎没有地方可以求助。

;

;“我们想要安全，我们是平民，不是士兵，孩子们在街上，这是一、二、三，四个年幼的孩子最后都流落街头，没有食物和水，甚至没有国际保护，也没有人权，”萨尔瓦·阿布·塔亚（Salwa Abu Taya）手里抱着一个孩子说道。

;

;“这是一种耻辱。他们被遗弃在街上，我们有什么错？他们把我们从一个地方转移到另一个地方。”

;

;加沙地带中部的舒哈达阿克萨医院表示，它已经开始运营没有药物了。

;

;加沙卫生部、内政部和哈马斯媒体办公室报道称，以色列夜间对整个地区的房屋和道路进行了密集轰炸。

;

;周四上午，哈马斯媒体称，飞机轰炸并摧毁了三座高层住宅楼，这些住宅楼容纳了数百户家庭，迫使他们逃离。

;

;在贾巴利亚难民营，人们在爆炸声和房屋毁坏中醒来。卫生官员和目击者称，救援人员正试图从废墟下救出人员。

;

;在一次事件中，两名儿童，一男一女，被废墟覆盖，但仍然活着。当一些人试图用手机手电筒和摄影师相机的灯光照亮该地区时，其中一名男孩显得很震惊。

;

;加沙居民说，欢乐的地方已经变成了充满痛苦和焦虑的地方。< /p>;

;“这是一个婚礼大厅，我们曾经在这里为我们的儿女举办喜事，现在我们睡在里面，我们在里面流离失所，”Amena Al-Kitnani 说。

;

;“婚礼殿堂不再有喜事，反而成了悲伤之地。”

; Thu, 19 Oct 2023 19:55:03 +0800 US general meets Egypt“s Sisi in push for aid to Gazahttps://reuters.com/article/israel-palestinians-egypt-usa/us-general-meets-egypts-sisi-in-push-for-aid-to-gaza-idUSKBN31J15C

;;运载埃及非政府组织为巴勒斯坦人提供的人道主义援助的卡车，等待埃及一侧拉法过境点的重新开放，进入加沙，以色列和巴勒斯坦伊斯兰组织哈马斯之间持续不断的冲突，2023 年 10 月 17 日，埃及拉法。 REUTERS/Stringer;
;

;负责中东美军的美国高级将领进行了一次未经宣布的访问周四前往埃及与埃及总统阿卜杜勒·法塔赫·塞西举行会谈，重点讨论以色列与哈马斯的战争以及如何向加沙地带提供援助。

;

;埃及的西奈半岛毗邻加沙地带及其;拉法过境点;援助从以色列境外直接进入加沙的唯一途径。这也是唯一不通往以色列领土的出口。

;

;周四，有 100 多辆卡车在埃及一侧的过境点附近等待，但预计援助物资不会在周五之前进入，埃及安全部门消息人士称。更多援助物资正在距离拉法约 45 公里（28 英里）的埃及城市阿里什举行。

;

;塞西办公室的一份声明称，与美国陆军上将迈克尔·“埃里克”·库里拉（Michael“Erik”Kurilla）进行了会谈。美国中央司令部特别提到了“加沙地带的事态发展”。

;

;“总统概述了埃及为缓和局势所做的努力，强调国际社会共同努力遏制危机并制止其蔓延的重要性。声明称，局势正在向危险方向升级。

;

;在开罗举行的会议上，库里拉还会见了埃及国防部长穆罕默德·扎基，会议召开之际，华盛顿和埃及一直在推动与以色列达成协议，以便向以色列运送援助物资。加沙。

;

;塞西办公室表示，鉴于人道主义状况不断恶化，以“可持续的方式”提供援助是当务之急。

;

;

;Voters in Venezuela will on Sunday choose a unity candidate from among 10 hopefuls to represent the country's opposition in 2024 presidential elections, when President Nicolas Maduro is expected to seek re-election.

;

;The primary is the first held by Venezuela's opposition in over a decade.

;

;Favorite Maria Corina Machado is ;barred from; holding public office, in a move criticized by the opposition and the US alike, and it is ;not clear; what will happen if she wins the primary.

;

;Two other candidates - former presidential candidate Henrique Capriles and ;ex-lawmaker Freddy Superlano; - have already withdrawn their candidacies because of similar disqualifications.

;

;The US government has conveyed to Maduro bans must be lifted for all opposition presidential candidates by ;the end of November; in exchange for sanction relief, a senior US official said on Wednesday.

;

;Here is a look at the top three candidates:

;

;Industrial engineer Machado, 56, a candidate for the Vente Venezuela party, has led polls by dozens of points, despite being disqualified.

;

;Machado, a mother of three, has said she plans to privatize state-owned oil company PDVSA if she goes on to win the presidential election next year.

;

;She has also set her sights on privatizing the Sidor steel company, ;restructuring public debt; and seeking financing from multilateral agencies like the World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank and the International Monetary Fund, among other ideas.

;

;"We must immediately ensure that economic growth translates into productive, well-paid employment, a growth of the middle class and a sense of well-being and hope," Machado recently told journalists.

;

;Prosperi, 45, a lawyer, is a member of the social democratic party Accion Democratica, from whose ranks have sprung several presidents.

;

;Born in Caracas but with family ties to the eastern state of Guarico, Prosperi has said that not being known at a national level could help him win over a skeptical population.

;

;The former lawmaker wants to rebuild PDVSA and Venezuela's iron and steel industries, as well as fix the ailing electrical grid, to boost growth.

;

;He has pledged to seek funding agreements with multilateral lenders and to support social spending, though he has not given details, and has also called for efforts to tackle corruption.

;

;Human rights activist and lawyer Solorzano has taken on the defense of some detainees considered by the opposition to be political prisoners.

;

;Solorzano, who defines herself as "center-right" and is also a former lawmaker, has represented hundreds of victims from Venezuela before the International Criminal Court and several United Nations commissions.

;

;She says that her government plan includes emergency actions on security, the economy and the legal system.

;

;Solorzano has proposed expanding the role of private investment in the energy sector and reorganizing PDVSA to remove functions unrelated to oil, which include food distribution and building houses.

;Streaming pioneer Netflix ;(NFLX.O); showed resilience by gaining more quarterly subscribers than in the past three years despite strikes by Hollywood's writers and actors, sending its shares up 13.5% in premarket trading on Thursday.

;

;Netflix capitalized on its heft in global production, as well as the economic hardships of its media rivals, to amass 247 million subscribers in the third quarter, a gain of nearly 9 million over the last three months.

;

;It was the greatest gain since the COVID-19 outbreak fueled unprecedented growth in early 2020.

;

;Shares rose to $393.45 in an indication that the company was set to add nearly $21 billion to its market capitalization.

;

;"The management deserves an Emmy for managing investor expectations," Bernstein analysts wrote in a note, adding that paid-sharing has opened up a bigger-than-expected market of potential subscribers for Netflix.

;

;Results from media rivals such as Walt Disney ;(DIS.N);, Paramount Global ;(PARA.O); and Warner Bros Discovery ;(WBD.O); will show the impact of the industry's months-long work stoppage, which began in May with strike by Hollywood's writers.

;

;Members of the Writers Guild of America settled this month, though actors, who walked off the job in July, remain on strike.

;

;US broadcast networks filled their fall lineups with repeats and reality shows, while rival streaming services delayed releases and had less foreign-language programs than Netflix, which could produce in more than 50 countries and languages.

;

;"Due to its large international presence, Netflix is positioned better than most entertainment companies in plugging programming gaps from the writers' and actors' strikes," said Insider Intelligence principal analyst Ross Benes.

;

;"With original US productions delayed and other TV and streaming companies no longer holding exclusive titles with vise grips, expect Netflix to revert to its past when many of its biggest shows were licensed," Benes said.

;

;A live-action adaptation of the Japanese manga series, "One Piece", which represented a collaboration between Netflix's US and Japanese content teams, ranked as the top show in 84 countries - a feat that even the popular sci-fi series "Stranger Things" did not accomplish.

;

;Meanwhile, the legal drama "Suits", which last aired on the USA Network in 2019, set viewing records when it landed on the streaming service in the summer, one of several television shows Netflix licensed from media competitors that are finding fresh audiences on Netflix.

;

;"Because of our distribution footprint and our recommendation system, we are able to take 'Suits', which had played on other streaming services, and pop it right into the center of the culture in a huge way," Netflix Co-CEO Ted Sarandos said during Wednesday's investor video.

;

;As talks between the union for actors and performers and major studios broke down last week, Sarandos saw parallels to how Netflix navigated "prolonged and pretty unpredictable production interruptions" during the pandemic.

;

;"These are the times that I'm glad we have such a rich and deep and broad program selection," Sarandos said.

;

;Still, Netflix is not free from strike disruptions. US-based shows such as mega-hit "Stranger Things" are on hold until actors return to work.

;

;Delays for some of its biggest shows are "problematic" for Netflix because "it doesn't have the same back catalog as Disney+ to fall back on", said Sophie Lund-Yates, lead equity analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown.

;;
;;Corn is loaded into a truck to be transported for ethanol production in Kelley, Iowa, US, January 21, 2020. REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton/File Photo;
;

;After a dry spring threatened to wither the US corn crop in the fields, farmers are harvesting what will likely be the country's third-largest crop ever.

;

;A bumper harvest will strain storage capacity and hold down prices of the world's most traded commodity crop. This will benefit customers who will pay less for corn used to feed livestock, dairy cows and egg-laying chickens or to make ethanol biofuel. But it will squeeze profits for farmers, who will store corn and hope for new demand from exports or new domestic uses.

;

;"At the end of June, I wasn't even sure it would make a crop," said Steve Pitstick, who farms nearly 5,000 acres just outside the Chicago suburbs in northern Illinois, where harvested fields stood next to crops ready to be cut.

;

;"But the timing of the rain, better genetics and better planting equipment set us up for success," Pitstick said during a rain delay in his harvest after more than two straight weeks of work. "It is surprisingly good."

;

;When the combines have finished the harvest and all the corn has been delivered for customer and exporter needs, the corn left in storage should exceed the amount that has sat in US silos for seven years, according to the US Agriculture Department (USDA).

;

;There could be 50% more corn in storage when the harvest starts in 2024 than when it started this year, the biggest single-year jump in supplies in nearly two decades. That bounty should further pressure the international corn price in Chicago.

;

;Already corn prices are trending near three-year lows at a time when some food prices are rising due to tight supplies of other staples like rice, stoking inflation worries.

;

;Top exporter Brazil also grew a ;record amount of corn;, and the global corn market, tight for years, now stands on the verge of a change in fundamentals to surplus for the first time since before the pandemic.

;

;Just 16 months ago corn prices were at their highest in a decade as the war in Ukraine disrupted supplies from the Black Sea breadbasket.

;

;"I think we are kind of in a headwind for corn for a couple of years," said Stephen Nicholson, global strategist for grains and oilseeds at Rabobank.

;

;Corn is the world's single biggest grain crop, and a surplus can quickly change the market tone to bearish for wheat, soy and other major crops.

;

;USDA forecast that domestic corn supplies would jump 55% to 2.111 billion bushels in the 2023/24 marketing year, helping push the global stockpile to a five-year high by September 2024.

;

;Corn buyers will benefit. The US chicken industry will spend less on corn for poultry feed after years of poor margins and closing plants.

;

;"I'm optimistic that the feed costs are going to be more manageable going forward," said Bill Roenigk, a consultant to the chicken industry.

;

;Cal-Maine Foods ;(CALM.O);, the biggest US egg producer, said its costs for feed per dozen eggs produced fell 10.5% in the quarter ended Sept. 2, primarily because of lower corn prices.

;

;But lower prices have dented incomes for corn farmers. Those with space in their grain silos will refrain from selling at a loss this fall and instead store the corn, hoping prices rise. Some may switch to planting more soybeans next spring.

;

;Pitstick, who devotes about half his acreage to corn, said he plans to store all the grain he has not already committed to sell. In the past 10 years, he has tripled his storage capacity to about 500,000 bushels.

;

;"You have only got one chance to grow a good crop but many opportunities to market it," he said.

;

;Still, rising interest rates make storing grain a more expensive and risky proposition. Some growers need to take out loans to fund their operations as they wait and hope corn prices will rise.

;

;US farmers also face high costs for the fuel and fertilizer needed to produce their corn. Net US farm income is expected to fall 23% at the end of this year from last year's record high.

;

;Harold Wolle, president of the US-based National Corn Growers, said that to use the surplus and keep farmers financially stable, it will be critical to boost exports, including tapping new markets, and grow ethanol demand with developments in the aviation fuel industry.

;

;"As prices decrease, our margins get squeezed," Wolle said. "It becomes harder and harder for farmers to have a profit margin when our prices get this low."
